questions.text: Metabolic syndrome criteria include all. except?
questions.solution:
Metabolic syndrome constitutes a constellation of metabolic abnormalities that increases the risk of cardiovascular disease and diabetes.

The main components of metabolic syndrome are

  • central obesity,
  • hypertriglyceridemia,
  • low HDL,
  • hyperglycemia and
  • hypertension

CONDITIONS ASSOCIATED WITH METABOLIC SYNDOME X:

Cardiovascular diseases, Diabetes mellitus, non alcoholic steatohepatitis, hyperuricemia, PCOS, obstructive sleep apnoea.

Other metabolic alterations that occur secondary to or accompany insulin resistance include increases in apoB and apoC-III, uric acid, prothrombotic factors (fibrinogen, plasminogen activator inhibitor 1), serum viscosity, asymmetric dimethylarginine, homocysteine, white blood cell count, proinflammatory cytokines, C-reactive protein, urine albumin/creatinine ratio.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: Patient undergoes B/L adrenalectomy in view of bilateral phaeochromocytoma . On post op day 1 patient develop lethargy, fatigue. BP normal, pulse normal. No evidence of loss of volume. The likely cause?
questions.solution:
Hypotension may occur during and after surgery for pheochromocytoma.

It occurs less frequently in patients who are adequately prepared by alpha blockade and volume expansion.

Managed by IV crystalloids or pressors if required.

Hypotension that occurs following bilateral adrenelectomy is due to adrenal cortical insufficiency.

Hypoglycemia can also occur in the immediate post op period and should be monitored.

questions.text: Nosocomial infection called after how many hours of hospital admission?
questions.solution:
Nosocomial infections are defined as those that are acquired after admission to the hospital which the patient has not been incubating during admission.

It appears first after 48 hours or more of hospital admission or within 30 days after having received hospital care.

Reveals Healthcare - associated infections: A public health problem.

questions.text: A patient developed vomiting 3-4 hrs after eating a meal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This question deals with bacterial food poisoning. Those bacteria which have preformed toxins have the shortest incubation period(<6 hours). Eg: S. aureus and B.cereus emetic type of food poisoning.

KEY TAKE AWAY

Incubation period of various bacterial food poisoning

questions.text: Patients well controlled on theophylline should not be given which antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Macrolides increase the level of theophylline by inhibiting Cyp450 and causes theophylline toxicity. Hence co administration should be avoided.

Agents which enhance theophylline metabolism primarily by inducing CYP1A2 lower its plasma level: dose has to be increased by the factor given in parenthesis.

Smoking, phenytoin, rifampicin, phenobarbitone, charcoal broiled meat meal.

Drugs which inhibit theophylline metabolism and increase its plasma level are-erythromycin, ciprofloxacin, cimetidine, oral contraceptives, allopurinol; dose should be reduced to 2/3.

questions.text: All are found in left ventricular failure. except?
questions.solution:
Tachycardia, pulsus alternans, elevated JVP, tender hepatomegaly, extremity edema, basal rales, pleural effusion, S3 gallop are all physical signs of hdeart failure.

Edema may be absent in acute HF especially in young even though venous pressure is high.

There will be features of pulmonary congestion on chest X ray.

  • Upper lobe venous redistribution,
  • Interstitial edema (kerley B lines),
  • alveolar edema,
  • cardiomegaly

Lung oligemia is not seen in cardiac failure

questions.text: Loss of pain/temperature sensation on ipsilateral face & c/l body due to thrombosis in?
questions.solution:
This sensory pattern is seen in Lateral medullary syndrome.

The arteries responsible may be vertebral> PICA>Superior, middle or inferior lateral medullary arteries.

So if vertebral artery is there in the option that should be the answer. Here it is given as anterior vertebral artery. So the most appropriate would be PICA.

The lateral medullary arteries are penetrating branches and lead to partial syndromes.

questions.text: Superior temporal gyrus lesion causes?
questions.solution:
Superior temporal gyrus is supplied by the inferior division of the MCA.

The area corresponds to Wernicke's area and lesion leads to sensory or Wernickes or fluent aphasia.

The motor speech area lies in the frontal lobe and is supplied by the superior division of MCA and it causes motor/Brocas/nonfluent aphasia.

questions.text: HIV patient with refractory diarrhea. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli and microsporidia are the common organisms causing diarrhea in HIV.

Cryptosporidium:

  • CD4 counts <100. May range from self limiting infection to chronic diarrhea.
  • Cause infection of biliary tree causing cholecystitis and pancreatitis secondary to papillary stenosis.
  • Diagnosis is by demonstration of oocysts in the stools that are acid fast.
  • Treatment is initiation of ART. Nitazoxanide may benefit.

Microsporidia: the commonest organism is Enterocytozoon bineuesi.

  • They are obligate intracellular parasites of the enteric cells. They are also found in cells outside the GIT like eye, brain, muscle, liver etc.
  • They have been associated with conjunctivitis and hepatitis.
  • They need chromotrope based stains for demonstration of the organism in the stools, because of their small size.
  • Electron microscopy of the stool or intestinal aspirate is needed for definitive diagnosis.
  • Treatment is reconstitution of immune system with ART. Albendazole may be effective.

Isospora belli:

  • clinical features are similar to cryptosporidium. More common in tropics and subtropics.
  • Oocysts are acid fast and are larger in size.
  • Treatment is very easy and effective with TMP-SMX

questions.text: Most common opportunistic infection after renal transplant?
questions.solution:
• CMV infection after transplant is associated with high morbidity and mortality.
  • Plasma viral load and a rise in IgM is diagnostic.
  • Treatment is Valganciclovir.

BK polyomavirus infection occurs due to reactivation of dormant virus in the urothelial cells.

  • It leads to graft rejection. Monitoring of viral load is needed.
  • Renal biopsy shows interstitial nephritis, cytopathic changes of virus in tubular epithelial cells and viral antigens in the allograft.
  • Leflunomide, Cidofovir, quinolones are effective against the viral helicase.
  • Reduction in dose of immunosuppression is needed. IvIg has been used with questionable benefit

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: First line drug for post-menopausal osteoporosis
questions.solution:
Postmenopausal women are susceptible to primary osteoporosis since osteoporosis is closely related to estrogen deficiency. During the menopausal transition period, the drop of estrogen leads to more bone resorption than formation, resulting in osteoporosis.

Bisphosphonates are the first line agent for postmenopausal osteoporosis.

ANTIRESORPTIVE AGENTS:

  • Bisphosphonates are the first line agent for postmenopausal osteoporosis.
  • Calcitonin : nasal and subcutaneous are approved for treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis, but not as the first line agent.
  • Strontium is used in patients not responding to other agents
  • Denosumab is the first human monoclonal antibody approved for treatment and prevention of osteoporosis.
  • Estrogens have fallen out of choice because of their side effects like DVT and risk of breast and endometrial malignancy.
  • Odanacatib, a cathepsin K inhibitor, inhibits the osteoclast collagenase enzyme, preventing bone resorption but not affecting osteoclast viability

ANABOLIC AGENTS:

Parathormone: Intermittent Teriparatide is indicated in moderate to severe osteoporosis.

Abaloparatide is a synthetic analogue of human PTHrP, which has significant homology to PTH and also binds the PTH type 1 receptor.

Romosozumab is a humanized antibody that blocks the osteocyte production of sclerostin, resulting in an increase in bone formation and decline in bone resorption.

questions.text: Water hammer pulse seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Water hammer pulse is seen in AR.

Corrigan pulse describes the excessive visible pulsations of arteries in patients with aortic valve insufficiency, most obvious in the head and superior extremity arteries when the patient is upright; in particular, the subclavian, carotid, temporal, brachial, and palmar arteries.

In MS the pulse will be low volume.

In AS the pulse will be slow rising low volume pulse(Parvus et tardus)

choices.text: Normal healthy person in the morning
Normal healthy person in the morning

questions.text: In comparison to a normal healthy person in the evening time. Which of these will not have an elevated cortisol?
questions.solution:
Normal circadian rhythm of ACTH starts to rise early in the morning prior to awakening, reaches a peak in the morning and levels will fall by evening.

Reduction in ACTH pulse occurs between 6PM and midnight.

Cortisol secretion increases in response to stress like hypotension, hypoglycemia, exercise, fever, surgery and burns.

In cushing's disease, the ACTH pulse frequency and amplitude is increased and hence the cortisol response and hence the circadian rhythm is lost.

questions.text: Which is not seen in ACTH deficiency?
questions.solution: In hypoadrenalism due to ACTH deficiency, hyperpigmentation is not seen. Instead alabaster coloured pale skin is seen. In primary adrenal insufficiency, due to POMC excess, hyperpigmentation is seen.

questions.text: Ph 7.2, bicarbonate-10, PC02-32, uncompensated metabolic acidosis is probably due to?
questions.solution:
Metabolic acidosis is characterized by an increase in the hydrogen ion concentration in the systemic circulation, resulting in a serum HCO3 less than 24 mEq/L.

Uncompensated Metabolic Acidosis: This occurs when there is a decrease in the HCO3 level without a resultant alteration (decrease) of the PaCO2 value.

Non-gap metabolic acidosis: is primarily due to the loss of bicarbonate, and the main causes of this condition are diarrhea and renal tubular acidosis. Additional and rarer etiologies include Addison's disease, ureterosigmoid or pancreatic fistulas, acetazolamide use, and hyperalimentation through TPN initiation. GI and renal losses of bicarbonate can be distinguished via urine anion gap analysis:

Urine AG = Urine Na + Urine K - Urine Cl

In your provided scenario with arterial blood gas values:

  • pH 7.2: Indicates acidemia, as it's lower than the normal reference range of arterial blood pH (7.35-7.45).
  • Bicarbonate (HCO3-) 10: This value is below the normal reference range (22-28 mEq/L), indicating a decrease in bicarbonate.
  • PCO2 32: Within the normal reference range (35-45 mm Hg), showing a compensatory response by the respiratory system.

These values are indicative of uncompensated metabolic acidosis, with the primary issue being a decrease in bicarbonate (HCO3-). This condition is likely due to the kidneys' loss of bicarbonate (HCO3-) into the urine, resulting in an accumulation of hydrogen ions (H+), contributing to the metabolic acidosis.

In uncompensated metabolic acidosis, the primary problem is not effectively compensated by the respiratory system, and the pH remains outside the normal range.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in pituitary apoplexy?
questions.solution:
Pituitary apoplexy is an endocrine emergency characterized by hypotension, hypoglycemia, head ache, bilateral visual symptoms, ophthalmoplegia and coma and death in severe cases.

It occurs in a pre existing adenoma of the pituitary or spontaneously in post partum, sickle cell anemia, diabetes, hypertension or shock.

questions.text: A patient with diffuse systemic sclerosis is presented to you with complained of progressive dyspnea and cough.respiratory examination shows bilateral crepitation.X-ray suggest bibasilar reticular shadow.What is the next step of investigation?
questions.solution:
This case scenario suggests interstitial lung disease in patients with diffuse systemic sclerosis.

In a patient with diffuse systemic sclerosis who presents with progressive dyspnea and cough, along with bilateral crepitations on respiratory examination and bibasilar reticular shadowing on X-ray, the next step of investigation is High-Resolution CT (HRCT) of the thorax. This choice is supported because:

HRCT Thorax: It is the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for detecting interstitial lung disease (ILD), which is common in patients with systemic sclerosis. HRCT can provide detailed images of the lung parenchyma, allowing for the identification of the extent and pattern of fibrosis, ground-glass opacities, and other interstitial changes.

2D ECHO: While echocardiography can be useful to evaluate for pulmonary hypertension, which can occur in systemic sclerosis, it does not provide detailed information about lung parenchymal disease.

CT Pulmonary Angiography: This is typically used to assess for pulmonary embolism. While it can show large vessel involvement, it is not the best choice for evaluating diffuse parenchymal lung disease in the context of systemic sclerosis.

Bronchoscopy: This invasive procedure is more useful for evaluating airway lesions, infections, or malignancies. It is not the first-line investigation for interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: A patient presented with nystagmus, ataxia and dysdiadokinesia. Identify the artery involved
questions.solution:
The symptoms of nystagmus, ataxia, and dysdiadochokinesia suggest involvement of the cerebellum or its connections.

The blood supply to the cerebellum is primarily from the branches of the vertebrobasilar system, which includes the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) and branches from the basilar artery, such as the superior cerebellar artery (SCA), anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA), and posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

Among the options given, the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) is part of this system and can be involved in cerebellar pathology.

questions.text: A known case of COPD with acute exacerbation of COPD. On examination patient is conscious and alert, pulse 110/min on examination bilateral wheeze is noted. Which of the following is not true?
questions.solution:
The question deals with the management of acute exacerbation of COPD. It includes

  • Inhaled bronchodilators, beta agonist or anticholinergics, either separately or together.
  • Systemic methylxanthines can be given
  • Antibiotics
  • Systemic steroids reduces length of hospital stay and future exacerbations.
  • Oxygen: to maintain SpO2≥90%.
  • NIV is indicated in patients with PCO2> 45

Invasive ventilation is indicated in patients with severe respiratory distress or hypercapnia despite initial therapy, severe hypoxia, hemodynamic instability, altered mentation, acidosis or respiratory arrest.

Permissive hypercapnia is allowed in COPD management and should not deter physicians from giving O2 to correct hypoxia, as O2 can cause modest increase in CO2 levels.

questions.text: Where is the defect in multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple sclerosis is a disorder of the CNS characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination and scarring.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system (CNS) characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (plaques or scarring), and neuronal loss; the course can be relapsing or progressive.

MS plaques typically develop at different times and in different CNS locations (i.e., MS is said to be disseminated in time and space).

Demyelination New MS lesions begin with perivenular cuffing by inflammatory mononuclear cells, predominantly T cells and macrophages, which also infiltrate the surrounding white matter.

At sites of inflammation, the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is disrupted, but unlike in vasculitis, the vessel wall is preserved.

At the leading edge of lesions, large numbers of cytotoxic CD8 cells are found. Involvement of the humoral immune system is also evident; small numbers of B lymphocytes infiltrate the nervous system, myelin-specific autoantibodies are present on degenerating myelin sheaths, and complement is activated.

questions.text: Patient is on a single drug for Rheumatoid arthritis for years. Symptoms are controlled. Then he developed corneal opacity. Which of the following medications was the patient on?
questions.solution:
Chloroquine:

  • Toxicity occurs in 6% of patients with a cumulative dose of 1000g over 5 years with continuing therapy.
  • Early eye symptoms include blurring of vision or defective accommodation, which resolves.
  • Retinal toxicity is the most feared one, described as bilateral Bulls eye maculopathy, with retinal pigment epithelial degeneration of the central macula with sparing of a small area in the fovea.
  • It is more seen with chloroquine than hydroxychloroquine.
  • Early diagnosis is possible by visual field analysis, even before fundal changes are evident.
  • With advanced disease, the visual symptoms progress despite the stoppage of the drug due to long half life of the drug in retina.
  • Corneal deposits are also common with CQ and HCQs which presents as halos around light and are reversible.
  • Hydroxychloroquine can cause cardiomyopathy and bonemarrow suppression

Methotrexate causes bone marrow suppression, hepatotoxicity, nephrotoxicity, pulmonary fibrosis and pseudolymphoma.

Leflunomide causes hepatotoxicity and myelosuppression.

Sulfasalazine causes granulocytopenia and hemolytic anemia in G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: A 50 year old female presented in OPD with irritability,sweating,palpitation,fatigue and weight loss with increased appetite with heat intolerance.Investigation will show?
questions.solution:
• The patient is having symptoms of thyroid hormone excess.
  • The commonest cause is Primary hyperthyroidism.
  • The biochemical changes that is seen in primary hyperthyroidism is low TSH and high T3/T4.

questions.text: What is the differentiating feature between IBS and organic GI disease?
questions.solution:
Irritable bowel syndrome is a functional bowel disorder which is non inflammatory. The unifying feature of inflammatory diarrhea due to any cause is the presence of leukocytes or leukocyte derived protein Calprotectin in stools.

  • Another inflammatory marker in stool is Fecal Lactoferrin, which is also present in activated neutrophils.
  • Both of them can be used in diagnosis of relapses of inflammatory bowel disease from IBS or bacterial overgrowth.
  • Fecal calprotectin is also having the advantage of being a sensitive marker of Colonic or ileocolonic inflammation rather than isolated ileal inflammation.

Abdominal pain, diarrhea and presence of mucous in stools can be seen in IBS as well as inflammatory diarrhea. Blood in stools, nocturnal symptoms and weight loss is uncommon in IBS.

choices.text: Ventricular diastole when the tricuspid valve is open
Ventricular diastole when the tricuspid valve is closed
Bulging of the tricuspid value into the right atrium

questions.text: C wave in JVP is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
a wave

  • represents atrial systole, occurs along with S4, preceeding theS1.
  • a wave will be hence absent in atrial fibrillation.
  • A prominent wave will be seen when the atria contracts against a non compliant right ventricle.
  • Canon a wave occurs in AV dissociation, where the atria contracts against a closed ventricle, as in Ventricular tachycardia.

X descent indicates a fall in the right atrial pressure, after the atrial systole. During this time, the tricuspid valves close and the valve is pushed into the atria, resulting in a small positive c wave, which interrupts the x descent. Hence it correlated with S1.

Immediately after the closure of the tricuspid valve, the ventricular systole begins, during which time, the atria is relaxed and the atrial filling takes place.

The atrial filling is represented by the v wave in JVP. When the filling of the atria is increased the v wave will be accentuated.

In tricuspid regurgitation, the tricuspid valves fail to close properly hence the c wave will merge with the v wave to form a giant v wave or the v wave is ventricularized.

They descent indicates the rapid filling of the ventricles. In tricuspid regurgitation, the y decent will be rapid. In conditions where the RV compliance is reduced or the tricuspid valve is stenosed, the y decent will be prolonged.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: Aquaporin 2 deficiency causes
questions.solution:
Diabetes Insipidus is a syndrome characterized by the excretion of large volume of dilute urine.

There are 4 types of DI

  • Central DI: Due to primary deficiency of vasopressin secretion by the neurohypopysis.
  • Primary polydipsia: Excessive water drinking leads to suppression of vasopressin.
  • Gestational diabetes insipidus: Due to the excessive degradation of vasopressin by an aminopeptidase produced by the placenta.

Nephrogenic DI: is due to the renal insensitivity to the action to AVP. It can be either acquired, due to drugs like LI or due to inherited mutations in the V2 genes. The most common type is inherited as a semi recessive X linked manner. There are AD and AR forms too.

questions.text: Dystrophin absent and presence of small muscle fibrils cause?
questions.solution:
Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy are the Dystrophinopaties.

DMD is characterized by absent dystrophin and Becker's muscular dystrophy is characterized by either decreased level or size of dystrophin.

Total absence of dystrophin points to the diagnosis of DMD.

Biopsy is not diagnostic in myopathies. So the microscopy will be almost the same for DMD and BMD.  Muscle biopsy in young ages will show degeneration and regeneration of muscle fibres with preserved architecture. There is no active inflammation except for myophagocytosis.

 As the disease progresses, the muscle fibers are replaced by fatty infiltration. The remaining muscle fibers show varying size from atrophic to hypertrophic.

Immunohistochemical staining shows absence of sarcolemmal staining in DMD and reduced staining in BMD.

They are both XL recessive inheritance. Dystrophin provides stability to the muscle fibre by acting as a bridge between the cytoskeleton inside the muscle fibre and the basement membrane outside the cell. DMD results from deletions or frameshift mutations in the dystrophin gene, leading to total absence of the protein, whereas BMD results in the formation of truncated variant of dystrophin that leads to partially functional protein.

questions.text: Large, Irregular, Friable deposits on the heart valves are seen in?
questions.solution: Vegetations in infective endocarditis are large and friable. The vegetations in acute rheumatic fever are small and tend to occur along the line of closure of valves. The vegetations of LIbman sacks are 1-3 mm warty deposits seen on either surface of any valves.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme elevation is/are less specific for the cholestasis jaundice?
questions.solution:
ENZYMES THAT REFLECT CHOLESTASIS

The activities of three enzymes-alkaline phosphatase, 5′-nucleotidase, and γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)-are usually elevated in cholestasis. Alkaline phosphatase and 5′-nucleotidase are found in or near the bile canalicular membrane of hepatocytes, whereas GGT is located in the endoplasmic reticulum and in bile duct epithelial cells.

Reflecting its more diffuse localization in the liver, GGT elevation in serum is less specific for cholestasis than are elevations of alkaline phosphatase or 5′- nucleotidase. Some have advocated the use of GGT to identify patients with occult alcohol use.

questions.text: A person was diagnosed with SVT and then he became unstable and ECG showed no change. Next line in management?
questions.solution: In a patient with supraventricular tachycardia and unstable BP, the treatment is cardioversion.
